{{Infobox politician |name = William Jay Gaynor |image name = Portrait of William Jay Gaynor.jpg |caption = |office = 94th [[Mayors of New York City|Mayor of New York City]] |term_start = January 1, 1910 |term_end = September 10, 1913 |predecessor = [[George B. McClellan Jr.]] |successor = [[Ardolph Loges Kline]] |birth_date = {{Birth date|1849|2|2}} |birth_place = [[Oriskany, New York]], U.S. |death_date = {{death date and age|1913|9|10|1849|2|2}} |death_place = On the [[Atlantic Ocean]] | spouse = {{marriage|Emma Vesta Hyde
|1876|1881|reason=divorced}}
{{marriage|Augusta Cole Mayer
|1886}} |children = 8 |party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] }} '''William Jay Gaynor''' (February 2, 1849 – September 10, 1913) was an American politician from [[New York City]], associated with the [[Tammany Hall]] [[political machine]]. He served as the 94th [[Mayor of New York City|mayor of the City of New York]] from 1910 to 1913, and previously as a [[New York Supreme Court]] Justice from 1893 to 1909. As mayor he was noted as a reformer who broke ranks and refused to take orders from the Tammany boss [[Charles Francis Murphy]]. ==Early life== Gaynor was born in [[Oriskany, New York]], on February 2, 1849 {{cite book|first=Ralph J. |last=Caliendo|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WN90SSAJ4JMC&pg=PA26&dq=William+Jay+Gaynor+1849&hl=en&sa=X&ei=mw68UYrXG4fbrAGc-YHoCQ&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=William%20Jay%20Gaynor%201849&f=false|title=New York City Mayors: Part II: the Mayors of Greater New York From 1898|page= 26}} to Keiron and Elizabeth (Handwright) Gaynor.{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |title=William Jay Gaynor as an intimate knew him. The Lawyer, the Judge, the Mayor, and the Man, Described by a Noted Editor-Author Whose Friendship with Him Covered a Long Period |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1913/09/21/100278994.pdf |quote=Apart from his family and from one trusted protege outside of his family, William Jay Gaynor had no intimates. He was a true and lasting friend. He never forgot an unselfish service. "I have never forgotten, you for a single day," he wrote, four years ago... |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=September 21, 1913 |accessdate=2007-06-14}}{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |title=Mrs. Charles Gulden |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1941/07/22/104296004.pdf |quote=Granddaughter of Late Mayor William J. Gaynor Dies |publisher=[[New York Times]] |date=July 22, 1941 |accessdate=2007-06-14}} He grew up on a farm with seven siblings. As a boy, he developed an interest in wandering the countryside where they lived, exploring nature and trying to figure out why things were the way they were. He was a studious boy, a trait which his father encouraged. As he was on the clumsy side, when it came to farmwork, his brother Tom usually took on the heavier chores. For his education, he first attended the local public school, then was sent to the Whiteboro [[Seminary#Other uses of the term|Seminary]]. The Gaynor family were [[Irish people|Irish]] and devout [[Roman Catholic]]s, thus, when weather permitted, on Sundays they would head to the nearby city of [[Utica, New York|Utica]] to attend [[mass (liturgy)|Mass]] at St. John's Church on Bleecker Street. As William entered his [[teenage]] years, he began to show a religious fervor that led his parents to think that he might have a [[vocation]] to the Church. Both to test this, and for reasons of affordability, he was enrolled in the Assumption Academy in Utica. This was staffed by the [[Brothers of the Christian Schools]], who had recently come to the United States from [[France]] in 1848. William flourished in that school, and soon decided that he did indeed wish to become a member of their [[Congregation (Catholic)|religious congregation]]. In December 1863, he was sent to [[New York City]] to enter the [[novitiate]] of the congregation. This was located at 44 East 2nd Street. The date of birth he gave at his admission was February 2, 1848, thus he was still fifteen at the time he was received. He was given the [[religious habit|habit]] of the Institute, and named Brother Adrian Denys. He spent the next four years in this house, both in training and soon in teaching in nearby [[parish school]]s. In 1868, he was one of a group of Brothers chosen to be sent to [[San Francisco]] to take care of [[St. Mary's College of California|St. Mary's College]] there. They sailed from New York on July 16, aboard the {{SS|Ocean Queen|1857|6}}. By this time, however, as well as the usual readings in [[history]], [[philosophy]] and the [[Church Fathers]] suggested to the Brothers, Gaynor had been reading and absorbing the reflection of a wide range of writers, mostly the ancient [[Stoicism|Stoic]] philosophers. One lifetime favorite which he found was the ''[[The Autobiography of Benjamin Franklin|Autobiography]]'' of [[Benjamin Franklin]], where he found much that resonated with his own way of thinking. The book was to be his lifelong companion. As a result, however, by the time the small group of Brothers had arrived at their destination, Gaynor had lost his belief in organized [[Christianity]] and had decided to leave the Institute. Because of his youth, he had never taken [[religious vows]], as he was too young to do so under the regulations of the Brothers, thus there was no [[canon law|canonical]] impediment to his departure. He made his way back home to Utica, where his family now lived, arriving late that same year. How he managed that journey he never shared, other than to say that it had not been an easy or pleasant experience. His father welcomed him back and helped him to secure a position with the law firm of Horatio and John Seymour, that he might learn enough law to read for the [[bar examination#United States|bar]]. This was to be the start of his entry into the political arena, as [[Horatio Seymour]] had recently served as [[Governor of New York]], and had just run as the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]]'s candidate for [[President of the United States]] against [[Ulysses S. Grant]].{{cite book |last=Lately |first=Thomas |title=The Man who mastered New York |publisher=William Morrow and Co., Inc. |year=1969 |pages=16–21}} ==In politics== Gaynor would disappoint Tammany Hall when they nominated him for mayor in 1909. Elected to the [[New York State Supreme Court]] in 1893, and appointed to the Appellate Division, Second Department in 1905, Gaynor's rulings were often cited around the country. His reputation as an honest reformer helped win him election as mayor in 1909. {{Citation needed|date=June 2010}} [[File:WJGaynor walks.jpg|thumb|left|Gaynor walks across the [[Brooklyn Bridge]] to his inauguration]] On January 1, 1910, he walked to [[New York City Hall|City Hall]] from his home in Brooklyn (#20 Eighth Avenue, [[Park Slope]]){{cite news |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9C00EEDA1239E433A25753C1A96E9C946196D6CF |title=Brooklyn Stirred. Had False Reports. Rumors Caused Borough Hall Officials to Order the Flags at Half-Mast |quote=Brooklyn, Mayor Gaynor's home borough, was greatly excited and deeply shocked by the news of the shooting of the city's chief executive. The earliest reports to reach the borough said that Mr. Gaynor had been killed. These spread rapidly through Brooklyn, and the local newspaper offices, telephone exchanges, and Police Headquarters were soon inundated by a flood of Inquiries which poured in from all sections. |publisher=[[The New York Times]] |date=1910-08-10 |accessdate=2008-01-06}} – it was the first time he had ever visited the seat of city government – and addressed the 1,500 people gathered to greet him: "I enter upon this office with the intention of doing the very best I can for the City of New York. That will have to suffice; I can do no more." In 1910 his daughter, Edith Augusta Gaynor, married [[Harry Kermit Vingut]]. They divorced in 1919 and she then married James Park.{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |title=Didn't Want Any of His Daughters to Wed Before They Were 25, the Delaware Version. Gave All the Details to the Attorney General at Wilmington Before the Marriage. |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F0CE5DE1230E233A25757C2A9609C946196D6CF |quote=An explanation was made to-day by Attorney General Andrew C. Gray, son of Federal Judge Gray, regarding the reason why Harry Kermit Vingut of New York came here yesterday with Edith Augusta Gaynor, daughter of Mayor Gaynor of New York. |work=[[New York Times]] |date=June 24, 1910 |accessdate=2008-12-08}} One of his granddaughters, Jean Rennard, married actor [[Fred Gwynne]]. Gaynor's marriage with Tammany Hall was short-lived; soon after taking office, he filled high level government posts with experts and city employees were chosen from civil service lists in the order they appeared, effectively curbing patronage and nepotism. As mayor, he railed against efforts to thwart the further development of the [[New York City Subway]] system. A strong willed but compassionate mayor, Gaynor once remarked, "The world does not grow better by force or by the policeman's club."{{cite book |last=Gaynor |first=William |authorlink=William Gaynor |title=Some of Mayor Gaynor's letters and speeches |publisher=Greaves Publishing Company |year=1913 |page=314 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-7kMAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA314 |accessdate=2010-08-10}} [[H. L. Mencken]], who covered the police beat and City Hall of Baltimore in his early days as a reporter, and so learned to know the good, the bad and the ugly of the species, had great respect for Gaynor both as a judge and as mayor. "Gaynor was that great rarity in American political history: a judge who actually believed in the Bill of Rights. When he sat on the bench in Brooklyn he tried to enforce it to the letter, to the natural scandal of his brethren of the ermine. Scarcely a day went by that he did not denounce the police for their tyrannies. He turned loose hundreds of prisoners, raged and roared from the bench, and wrote thousands of letters on the subject, many of them magnificent expositions of Jeffersonian doctrine. Unfortunately, his strange ideas alarmed the general run of respectable New Yorkers quite as much as they alarmed his fellow judges, and so he was always in hot water. When Tammany, with sardonic humor, made him mayor, he began an heroic but vain effort to give New York decent government. He might as well have tried to make the stockyards of Chicago smell like a field of asphodel. In the end, worn out and embittered by the struggle, he died unlamented, and today political historians scarcely mention him. Yet he was a great political philosopher and a great soul. It is the tragedy of the Republic that such men are so few, and that their efforts, when they appear, go for so little."H. L. Mencken, "New American Statesmen," ''American Mercury'', v. 25, no. 98 (February 1932) 252. A review of ''Gaynor'' (New York: International Press) by Louis Heaton Pink and some other books. ==Georgist views on political economy== Gaynor read the first edition of [[Henry George]]'s famous treatise ''[[Progress and Poverty]]'' said that [[Georgism]] was the "perfect" and "optimal" system ("admitted by philosophers and economists the world over"). However, he objected to what he perceived as George's intent to take all land rent for public use at once. Instead, Gaynor favored a slow transition over many years. He was unaware of fact that removing other taxes would increase land rent, yet by his calculations there was enough land rent to replace all taxes with a [[land value tax]].{{cite book|last==Gaynor|first= William Jay|title=Some of Mayor Gaynor's letters and speeches|publisher=Greaves Pub. Co.|year= 1913|pages= 214–221|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-7kMAAAAYAAJ}} ==Assassination attempt== [[Image:Wjgaynor shot2.jpg|thumb|left|Gaynor moments after the assassination attempt. August 9, 1910. At left is [[Robert Todd Lincoln]] and at right is [[Benjamin C. Marsh]]. A second picture of Gaynor after he was shot is at ''[[New York Tribune]] August 10, 1910.{{cite web|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1910-08-10/ed-1/seq-1/|title=New-York tribune. (New York [N.Y.]) 1866-1924, August 10, 1910, Image 1|date=10 August 1910|publisher=|via=chroniclingamerica.loc.gov}}]] Early in his term, Gaynor was shot in the throat by [[James J. Gallagher]],{{cite web|url=http://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=LAH19100814.2.25&srpos=3&e=--1910---1910--en--20--1--txt-txIN-Gaynor+shot------|title=Los Angeles Herald 14 August 1910 — California Digital Newspaper Collection|website=cdnc.ucr.edu}} a discharged city employee who had been a New York dock Night Watchman from April 7, 1903, to July 19, 1910.{{cite web|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85058140/1910-08-10/ed-1/seq-2/|title=The Salt Lake herald-Republican. (Salt Lake City, Utah) 1909-1918, August 10, 1910, Image 2|date=10 August 1910|publisher=|pages=2|via=chroniclingamerica.loc.gov}} Gaynor remains the only New York City mayor to be hit by a bullet during an assassination attempt. The violent incident happened on board the Europe-bound {{SS|Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse}}, which was docked at [[Hoboken, New Jersey]]. Gallagher died in a prison in [[Trenton, New Jersey]], from [[paresis]] on February 4, 1913,{{cite web|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85038615/1913-02-04/ed-1/seq-2/|title=The times dispatch. (Richmond, Va.) 1903-1914, February 04, 1913, Image 2|date=4 February 1913|publisher=|pages=2|via=chroniclingamerica.loc.gov}} the same year as Gaynor's death.{{cite news |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A0CEED8163FE633A25757C0A9649C946296D6CF |title=Mayor's Assailant Dead Of Paresis. Gallagher, Who Shot Him on Board Ship, Dies in Trenton State Hospital |work=[[New York Times]] |accessdate=July 29, 2013}} Observing Gaynor in conversation, ''[[New York World]]'' photographer William Warnecke snapped what he thought would be a typical, if uneventful, photo of the new Mayor. Instead, Warnecke captured the very moment that Gallagher, at point-blank range, shot a bullet through Gaynor's neck. The rarely seen snapshot remains one of the most highly praised photographs in the history of [[photojournalism]].{{cite web |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1910/08/10/102045940.pdf |first= |last= |authorlink= |title=Story of Shooting told by Witnesses. Mayor's Official Family Relate What They Did to Aid Their Stricken Chief. |quote=This is the story of the shooting of Mayor Gaynor as told by eye-witnesses, among whom were Robert Adamson, the Mayor's secretary; Corporation Counsel Watson, Street Cleaning Commissioner Edwards, and Water Commissioner Thompson. It was Mr. Edwards who beat the Mayor's assailant into submission. ... |publisher=[[New York Times]] |date=August 10, 1910 |accessdate=2007-06-14}} ==Death== Although Gaynor quickly recovered, the bullet remained lodged in his throat for the next three years. During his term as mayor, Gaynor was widely considered a strong candidate for Governor or President. Tammany Hall refused to nominate him for reelection to a second term, but after accepting the nomination from an independent group of voters, he set sail for Europe aboard {{RMS|Baltic|1903|6}}. Six days later, on September 10, 1913, Gaynor died suddenly on a deck chair aboard the liner. After his death, doctors concluded that he died of a heart attack, and that his old wound was at most a minor contributing factor.{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |title=Mayor Gaynor Dies In Deck Chair On Liner. Stricken While Alone. Kline Sworn In As City's Head. Rufus Gaynor Finds His Father Unconscious. End Comes Quickly |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F50A1EFD3A5813738DDDAB0994D1405B838DF1D3 |quote=[[London]], September 11, 1913. Mayor William J. Gaynor of New York died in his steamer chair on board the steamship Baltic early Wednesday afternoon when the liner was 400 miles off the Irish Coast. His death was due to a sudden heart attack. |publisher=[[New York Times]] |date=September 12, 1913 |accessdate=2007-06-14}} Gaynor is interred at [[Green-Wood Cemetery]] in [[Brooklyn]], [[New York (state)|New York]]. The [[Fire Department of New York]] operated a [[fireboat]] named [[William J. Gaynor (fireboat)|''William J. Gaynor'']] from 1914 to 1961.{{cite web |url=http://marine1fdny.com/fireboat_history_new.php |title=Fireboats Through The Years |author=Clarence E. Meek |date=July 1954 |accessdate=2015-06-28 |deadurl=No }} {{clearleft}} ==See also== *[[William Brown Meloney (1878–1925)]], Gaynor's executive secretary *[[List of mayors of New York City]] ==References== '''Explanatory notes''' {{Reflist|group=notes}} '''Citations''' {{reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== * Finegold, Kenneth. "Traditional Reform, Municipal Populism, and Progressivism Challenges to Machine Politics in Early-Twentieth-Century New York City." ''Urban Affairs Review'' (1995) 31#1 pp: 20-42. [http://uar.sagepub.com/content/31/1/20.short online] * Smith, Mortimer B. ''William Jay Gaynor: Mayor of New York'' (1951) * Thomas, Lately. ''The mayor who mastered New York: the life and opinions of William J. Gaynor'' (1969) ==External links== {{Commons category|William Jay Gaynor}} *[http://www.nycgovparks.org/sub_your_park/historical_signs/hs_historical_sign.php?id=12525 William Jay Gaynor monument] *[http://www.green-wood.com/burial_results/index.php Green-Wood Cemetery Burial Search] {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{succession box | before = [[George B. McClellan Jr.]] |title=[[List of mayors of New York City|Mayor of New York City]] | years = 1910–1913 | after = [[Ardolph Loges Kline]]}} {{s-end}} {{Mayors of New York City}} {{Democratic NYC mayoral nominees}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gaynor, William Jay}} [[Category:1849 births]] [[Category:1913 deaths]] [[Category:American people of Irish descent]] [[Category:American shooting survivors]] [[Category:Burials at Green-Wood Cemetery]] [[Category:Mayors of New York City]] [[Category:New York (state) Democrats]] [[Category:People from Whitestown, New York]] [[Category:People who died at sea]] [[Category:United States presidential candidates, 1912]] [[Category:20th-century American politicians]] [[Category:19th-century American politicians]]

{{Infobox FBI Ten Most Wanted | name = Yaser Abdel Said | image0 = Yaser-said.jpeg | image = Yaser Abdel Said.png | image_size = | alt = | caption = Mugshot of Yaser | charge = * [[Unlawful Flight to Avoid Prosecution]] * Capital Murder - Multiple | reward = $100,000 | alias = Yaser Abdel Fattah Mohammad Said, Yaser Abdel Saeed | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1957|1|27}} | birth_place = [[Sinai peninsula|Sinai]], [[Republic of Egypt (1953–58)|Egypt]] | nationality = Egyptian | ethnicity = Arab | gender = Male | height = {{height|ft=6|in=2}} | weight = {{convert|180|lb|kg|abbr=on}} | occupation = Taxi driver | parents = | siblings = | spouse = Patricia Owens | children = Amina Said, Sarah Said, Islam Said | conviction = | conviction_penalty = | conviction_status = | added_date = December 4, 2014 | caught_date = | remove_date = | surrendered_date = ''surrendered date'' | number = 504 | status = dead This <!-- Status choices: Caught Dead Killed/Captured Removed Surrendered, No status or other status defaults to currently on list --> }} '''Yaser Abdel Said''' (born January 27, 1957) is a fugitive on the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] [[Ten Most Wanted List]]. An [[Egyptians|Egyptian]] resident of the United States, he is wanted for the murder of his two teenage daughters in [[Irving, Texas]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fbi.gov/wanted/topten/yaser-abdel-said/view|title=FBI — YASER ABDEL SAID|work=[[FBI]]|accessdate=31 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fbi.gov/news/stories/2014/december/new-top-ten-fugitive-help-us-find-a-murderer|title=FBI — New Top Ten Fugitive: Help Us Find a Murderer|work=[[FBI]]|accessdate=31 July 2015}}</ref>
Said, who is reported to have been very controlling of his family, is believed to have felt that his daughters, Amina, 18, and Sarah, 17, [[Honor killing|had dishonored the family]] by refusing to adhere to traditional standards of Egyptian cultural behavior. On January 1, 2008, he lured them into his taxi cab on the pretense of taking them out to eat, and shot them in the cab.<ref name="dallasnews.com">{{cite web|url=http://crimeblog.dallasnews.com/2014/12/lewisville-cab-driver-sought-for-honor-killings-of-daughters-added-to-fbis-ten-most-wanted-list.html/|title=Lewisville cab driver sought for "honor killings" of daughters added to FBI's Ten Most Wanted list|work=[[The Dallas Morning News]] Crime Blog|accessdate=31 July 2015}}</ref> Said has evaded police capture, and remains at large.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2862305/Yaser-Abdel-Said-Taxi-driver-suspected-murdering-two-teen-daughters-2008-New-Year-s-Day-honor-killings-added-FBI-Wanted-list-100-000-bounty.html| title=Yaser Abdel Said suspected of murdering his daughters added to FBI Most Wanted list - Daily Mail Online| work=[[Mail Online]]| accessdate=31 July 2015}}</ref>
==Family== Yaser Said married Patricia "Tissie" Owens in February 1987; he was 30 and she was 15.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.dallasobserver.com/news/american-girls-6419640| title=American Girls| author=Glenna Whitley| work=[[Dallas Observer]]| accessdate=31 July 2015}}</ref> Patricia had later alleged that Yaser had abused her during their marriage.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2012/05/29/alleged-honor-killing-suspect-yaser-said-could-be-hiding-in-plain-sight-as-new/| title=Texas 'honor killing' suspect Yaser Said could be hiding in plain sight as NYC cabbie, private investigator says| author=Perry Chiaramonte| work=[[Fox News]]| accessdate=31 July 2015}}</ref> Amina was born in 1989, whilst Sarah was born in 1990.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/story?id=4102781&page=1&singlePage=true| title='Honor Killing' Motive for Slain Sisters?| author=ABC News| work=[[ABC News]]| accessdate=31 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://pix11.com/2015/07/10/my-dad-shot-me-search-exceeds-7-years-for-father-suspected-of-killing-daugters/| title="My dad shot me!": Search exceeds 7 years for father suspected of killing daughters - New York's PIX11 / WPIX-TV| work=[[WPIX|New York's PIX11]]| accessdate=31 July 2015}}</ref> They also had an older son named Islam Said who was born in 1988 and another daughter from a previous woman born 1987.
==Abuse of Amina and Sarah== The girls confessed to a few friends that the abuse continued. "He treats me like a whore," Sarah wrote in an [[instant message]] conversation to a friend. On several occasions, Amina appeared at school with [[bruise]]s, and at one point, had a split lip. Amina informed her friends that the wounds were inflicted by her father, and her mother refused to allow her to seek medical attention.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.americanthinker.com/articles/2012/07/the_said_honor_murders_indict_the_mother.html| title=Articles: The Said Honor Murders: Indict the Mother| work=[[American Thinker]]| accessdate=31 July 2015}}</ref>
Yaser would often spy on his daughters, often by video or audio-taping them without their knowledge.<ref name=boyfriend>{{cite web| url=http://www.businessinsider.com/inside-the-honor-killing-of-amina-said-2014-9| title=My Teenage Sweetheart Was Killed to Preserve Her Family's 'Honour'| work=[[Business Insider]]| author=Joseph Moreno| date=25 Sep 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.dallasobserver.com/2008-06-19/news/american-girls/|title=American Girls| author=Glenna Whitley| work=[[Dallas Observer]]| accessdate=31 July 2015}}</ref> Amina stated she was afraid of using the public telephone "because he [Yaser] gets in everywhere, he knows everything".<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.thepriceofhonorfilm.com| title=The Price of Honor| work=The Price of Honor| accessdate=31 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite AV media| url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Pc3b2ueYPpg| title=Guy kills 2 daughters and flees the scene (Warning, Graphic!)| date=24 June 2009| work=[[YouTube]]| accessdate=31 July 2015}}</ref> She also reportedly wrote in emails that her father intended to kill her.<ref name="dallasnews.com"/> When she was 16, Yaser took Amina to Egypt, allegedly to arrange a marriage to a much older friend of his, but Amina rejected the marriage. Sarah got an after-school job working in a [[convenience store]]. Yaser soon video-taped her at work and punished her for smiling too much at the customers.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/06/18/us-violence-women-honourkillings-idUSKBN0OY2UK20150618| title=Two girls murdered in Texas taxi: Were they honor killings?| work=[[Reuters]]| date=18 Jun 2015}}</ref>
Amina began dating a boy who she met while taking [[Taekwondo]] classes. When Yaser was out of the country, she felt anxious about meeting her boyfriend, imagining that Yaser would be watching her with binoculars.<ref name=boyfriend/> Amina advised her boyfriend not to call or text her if she sent a codeword to him, because Yaser would go through her phone. Soon afterwards, Yaser found a note that she had written to her boyfriend. Amina told him that the writings were to an imaginary boyfriend. Yaser, not trusting Amina, continued his search in order to uncover Amina's relationship.
Yaser moved his family {{convert|60|mi}} to a new house in [[Lewisville, Texas|Lewisville]], [[Texas]],<ref name=boyfriend/> prompting Amina to make plans to run away with her boyfriend, get married in [[Las Vegas Valley|Vegas]], and start a new life. Her boyfriend then quit high school in order to earn money working, so that he could save up enough money in order to help her leave. Her boyfriend had also stated: "[Yaser] regularly threatened to kill Amina, and she knew he meant it."<ref name=boyfriend/> Amina was worried that her boyfriend would be killed by her father, and she refused to give her father his name while she was beaten, following Yaser's persistent accusations.
==Murders of Amina and Sarah== After Christmas,<ref name=boyfriend/> Amina and Sarah ran away with their mother, Patricia, to Tulsa, Oklahoma, where Amina's boyfriend had relatives. Patricia had allegedly told her daughters that December 31 was her mother's death anniversary and that she wanted to drive to [[East Texas]] to put flowers on her grave, later telling them they would return to Yaser. Sarah reluctantly went, while Amina refused. Patricia drove to Amina's friend's house and pounded on the door, starting an argument with Amina to try and convince her to return to Yaser. Amina still refused to go. Patricia insisted and stood unmoved in the doorway, saying that her father had forgiven her and would like the girls to return home.
On January 1, 2008, Yaser took Amina and Sarah to his taxi cab, and kissed them, telling them he was taking them out to eat. Patricia had wanted to come along, but Yaser had told her that he wanted to talk to the girls alone. He drove them both to Irving, where he allegedly shot both girls to death in the taxi cab. Amina instantly died, while Sarah managed to call [[9-1-1|911]] before she died, stating "Help, my dad shot me! I'm dying, I'm dying!".<ref>{{cite AV media| url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4ZjK8ZS4Qa0| title=Amina & Sarah Said 911 Call| date=23 October 2014| work=[[YouTube]]| accessdate=31 July 2015}}</ref> Yaser's taxi was soon discovered by another cab driver outside a hotel.<ref>{{cite AV media| url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kf-kEkIKuJU| title=Disturbing 911 call- "I'm dying, I'm dying"| date=19 July 2009| work=[[YouTube]]| accessdate=31 July 2015}}</ref>
==Aftermath== Following the murders, Yaser vanished, although there is no record of him flying to [[Egypt]]. The [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] believes that Yaser may now be driving a cab in [[New York City]].<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.fbi.gov/wanted/topten/yaser-abdel-said/view/| title=FBI — YASER ABDEL SAID| work=FBI| accessdate=31 July 2015}}</ref> A cab driver reported that he may have seen Yaser driving a cab in [[Newark Liberty International Airport|Newark Airport]].<ref>{{cite AV media| url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Tib_vty9MCA| title=Honor Killer Yaser Abdel Said is now on FBI top 10 Most Wanted, About Time!| date=14 April 2014| work=YouTube| accessdate=31 July 2015}}</ref> Some people have also allegedly seen Yaser in New York City driving a light colored or champagne colored older Mercedes and working as a cab driver in 2014 and FBI was informed of this. <ref>https://www.reddit.com/r/UnresolvedMysteries/comments/8pshye/yaser_abdel_said_honour_killer_at_large_2008/ </ref> On December 4, 2014, Yaser was added to the [[FBI Ten Most Wanted Fugitives|FBI's Ten Most Wanted Fugitives list]], with a $100,000 reward with any information leading to the arrest of Yaser.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.fbi.gov/newyork/press-releases/2013/new-reward-issued-for-fbi-fugitive-yaser-abdel-said| title=FBI — New Reward Issued for FBI Fugitive Yaser Abdel Said| work=[[FBI]]| accessdate=31 July 2018}}</ref>
